definition:
A *sinusoid* is a curve of the form $$\begin{aligned}
  \mathbb{R}&\to& \mathbb{R}^2 \\
   t&\mapsto & (t,\,\sin{kt}),\end{aligned}$$ where $k>0$ is a parameter
determining the oscillation.

The basic sinusoid, the curve $$y  = \sin{x}$$ in the $xy$-plane,
oscillates periodically with the , $2\pi$, as $x$ increases.

![image](sinusoid)

-   On the interval $[0,\,\frac{\pi}{2}]$, the curve is ascending
    because the , $\cos{x}$, is positive for acute angles $x$.

-   Consequently, on the interval $[\frac{\pi}{2},\,\pi]$,the supplement
    formula $\sin{(\pi-x)} = \sin{x}$ tells that the sinusoid is
    descending.

-   Thus we get on the whole interval $[0,\,\pi]$ a cap-formed
    ($\smallfrown$) arc.

-   Because , we have on the interval $[-\pi,\,0]$ the of the cap, a
    cup-formed ($\smallsmile$) arc.

-   All in all, on the period interval $[-\pi,\,\pi]$ the sinusoid
    consists of the consecutive cup and cap, together a lying-S formed
    ($\backsim$) arc.

-   The same is repeated on each other period interval
    $[(2n\!-\!1)\pi,\,(2n\!+\!1)\pi]$ where $n\in\mathbb{Z}$.
